Inventions/Accomplishment: First black person to hold a department chair at Harvard Medical School
Invented a method of fabricating an imaging X-ray spectrometer

Responsible for the construction of many roads and bridges, including the Whitehurst Freeway, the Tidal Basin Bridge, and an extension to the Baltimore-Washington Parkway.
Folding bed
Extracted chaulmoogra oil for the treatment of Hansen's disease (leprosy)
Constructed wooden clock; astronomer; mathematician; assisted in the survey of the original boundaries of the District of Columbia; authored a series of almanacs and ephemerides; naturalist
Work on diffeomorphisms and symplectomorphisms
First black woman to receive a patent for a web-based software invention, LinkLine, an Equal Employment Opportunity case management and tracking software

First black female physician to receive a patent for a medical invention; inventions relate to cataract surgery and include the Laserphaco Probe, which revolutionized the industry in the 1980s, and an ultrasound technique for treatment

occupation_s: Farmer; carpenter; blacksmith; railroad worker; businessman; inventor
Inventions/Accomplishment: Janney coupler improvements; invented the car device #594,059 dated November 23, 1897; rotary engine patent #478,271 dated July 5, 1892
Invented chair with sliding skin (2004) and the quantitative display apparatus (2005)

Gastroscope pioneer - In addition to his long and distinguished medical career, Berry was active in teaching, writing, and community public service. The latter included work in civil rights, on the racial problems of public health, and with the African Methodist Episcopal Church.
Probability theory and Markov chain theorist

Brain tumor surgery and research - In 1997, Time magazine featured Black on the cover of a special edition called "Heroes of Medicine". The accompanying article described Black's reputation as a surgeon who would operate on tumors that other doctors would not, as well as aspects of his medical research, including his discovery that the peptide bradykinin can be effective in opening the blood–brain barrier.

First proposed the Blackwell channel model used in coding theory and information theory; one of the eponyms of the Rao-Blackwell theorem, which is a process that significantly improves crude statistical estimators
Second black inventor to issue a patent; invented seed planter and cotton planter.
Silicon retina able to process images in the same manner as a living retina
Ironing board allowing sleeves of women's garments to be ironed more easily
First black person to receive a PhD in any subject; received physics doctorate from Yale University in 1876
Pathologist and geneticist; Professor Emeritus Pritzker School of Medicine; first tenured black professor at the University of Chicago Division of Biological Sciences
Artificial heart pacemaker control unit

Protein structure research

Pediatric neurosurgery at Johns Hopkins University; first surgeon to successfully separate craniopagus twins

Discovered hundreds of uses for previously useless vegetables and fruits, principally the peanut

occupation_s: Electrician; construction; international businessman; and aviation pioneer
Inventions/Accomplishment: Designed long-distance flight airplane; the only black person to invent and display the airplane at the 1911 First Industrial Air Show held in conjunction with the Auto Show at Grand Central Palace in Manhattan in New York City
Valuable contributions to several fields: medicine, biology, food science, and astrochemistry
Conducted 1940s experiments using dolls to study children's attitudes about race
First Black president of the American Psychological Association
Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning; received some 40 US patents relating to HVAC systems
Organic ionogen for aluminum electrolytic capacitors, cationic dialdehyde polysaccharides for wet strength paper and others, US Patent Office US Pat #3609467 US Pat #3547423 and others
Expert on jellyfish hydrodynamics and designer of a vertical-axis wind farm adapted from schooling fish

Led the team that developed the ISA bus, and led the design team responsible for creating the first one-gigahertz computer processor chip
Developed improved techniques for blood storage

Explorer; first modern European outsider to confirm the existence of gorillas, and later the Pygmy people of central Africa; identified as white throughout life, but his mother was a mulatto woman; settled in America and considered it his country
Work at the Lewis Research Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its predecessor, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics
First African American with a PhD in computer science; software inventor including OfficeTalk at Xerox PARC
Drag racing engineer and driver
Chemistry doctorate, first received (1943, University of California, Berkeley)
Work on supersymmetry, supergravity, and superstring theory
Cabinet bed invention; first black woman to receive a patent in the United States
Awarded the first Presidential Endowed Chair at Clemson University in honor of his accomplishments
The first black professor at Harvard, Boston dentist, and inventor of a wooden golf tee.
Graves' research concerns the evolutionary genetics of postponed aging and biological concepts of race in humans,
Specializes in syntax and the study of African American English
Greenaugh attended college early and became the first African American to receive a doctorate in Nuclear Engineering at the University of Maryland.

contributed to the science of food preservation. By the end of his career, Hall had amassed 59 United States patents, and a number of his inventions were also patented in other countries.
Co-discovered Rutherfordium (element 104) and Dubnium (element 105) at Lawrence Livermore Laboratory
Inventor at Bell Laboratories
best known for establishing the mechanisms in the Maillard reaction pathway.

IBM's 1st black Distinguished Engineer and 2nd black IBM Fellow.  Inventor of several software engineering techniques including system and methods for locating mobile devices using location and presence information
Co-inventor of imaging x-ray spectrometer.
Helped develop technologies leading to the invention of the touch-tone telephone, portable fax, solar cells, fiber optic cables, and the technology enabling caller ID and call waiting.
Duke University neuroscience bird songs studies
First black person to be granted a patent (for a dry cleaning process called dry scouring)
Held patent for improvements to the bicycle frame, specifically so it could be taken apart for compact storage
Invented Double Sided Guitar
Invented refrigerated truck systems
First to synthesize the natural product physostigmine; earned 130 chemical patents; lauded for humanitarian achievements

occupation_s: Woods Hole Marine Biology Institute biologist
Inventions/Accomplishment: Provided basic and initial descriptions of the structure-function-property relationship of the plasma membrane of biological cells
Work in tracing the ancestry of African Americans via DNA testing
Organ transplantation pioneer, particularly renal transplant research and surgery; author or co-author of 172 articles in scientific publications

Worked as a draftsman for both Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas Edison; became a member of Edison's Pioneers and served as an expert witness in many light bulb litigation lawsuits; said to have invented the water closet
Designer of Fairchild Channel F, the first programmable ROM cartridge-based video game console

Paul and Aileen Russell Professor, Pritzker School of Medicine; MacArthur Fellow, Searle Scholar, founder and chairman, Avocet Polymer Technologies, Inc.; founder and chairman, Renacyte BioMolecular Technologies, Inc; discovered use of surfactant copolym

Beebe Steven Lynk (1872–1948) served as the professor of medical Latin botany and materia medica at the University of West Tennessee. She was an active member of the early black women's club movement, authoring a book, 'Advice to Colored Women' in 1896. An advocate for women's rights, she was a member of the National Federation of Women's Clubs. Her book reflected the organization's mission of advancing the status of African-American women through education and respectability.
First black person to study and work as a professionally trained nurse in the United States
Shoe assembly Machine
His discoveries allowed chemists around the world to create inexpensive peroxide compounds
Invented a version of the automatic lubricator for steam engines, McCoy learned a great deal of his skills from a mechanical apprenticeship when he was age fifteen  .
Known for inventing the world's smallest self-contained autonomous robots
Specializes in the study of creole language formation
Designed a steam operated propeller to provide propulsion to boats in shallow water
First Black American woman to earn a PhD in Physics (University of Michigan Ann Arbor 1972) on vibrational analysis of secondary chlorides

Invented an early version of a gas mask called a smoke hood, and created the first traffic light that included a third "warning" position which is standard today. Morgan also developed a chemical that was used in hair products for hair-straightening.
Pioneer in fiber optic technology
Invented electric elevator doors that automatically open and close
Studies toxic metals in the environment; supporter of the lead poisoning thesis of the decline of the Roman Empire

Ethnic studies in education and John Uzo Ogbu (May 9, 1939 – August 20, 2003) was a Nigerian-American anthropologist and professor known for his theories on observed phenomena involving race and intelligence, especially how race and ethnic differences played out in educational and economic achievement.

Inventions in oil refining
Furnace for Central Heating

Manhattan Project, worked with Albert Einstein and Enrico Fermi

In 1966, his being named head of the Department of Orthodontics made him the first black person to lead a department at the University of Illinois at Chicago College of Dentistry. He was the first black American orthodontist to open an office in the Chicago downtown Loop area, and the first black American in Illinois to be licensed as a commercial aviator.
Inventor of the multiple-effect evaporator
Investigated possible role of arsenic in the death of Zachary Taylor; interim president of Florida A&M University
A runner for stoops (1896), bag closure device (1898), a wrinkle-preventing trouser stretcher (1899), a garment-hanger (1903), and a holder for brooms and like articles.

He holds patents and continues to invent and innovate in the emerging area of next generation broadband wireless networks, technologies and services, which is frequently referred to as 4G. Russell was inducted into the United States' National Academy of Engineering during the Clinton Administration for his contribution to the field of Wireless Communication. He pioneered the field of digital cellular communication in the 1980s through the use of high power linear amplification and low bit rate voice encoding technologies and received a patent in 1992 (US patent #5,084,869) for his work in the area of digital cellular base station design.
Patent for hot comb

He is best known for his work on stereotype threat and its application to minority student academic performance. His earlier work dealt with research on the self (like self-image and self-affirmation) as well as the role of self-regulation in addictive behaviors.

From 2000 to 2002 Stiff was president of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. Under his leadership, the NCTM pushed for a greater emphasis on basic computational skills in elementary and secondary school mathematics education, and for an appropriate emphasis on conceptual understanding.

Mwende Window Snyder, better known as Window Snyder (born 1975) is an American computer security expert, currently working as the Chief Security Officer at Square, Inc.. She has previously been a top security officer at Apple, Fastly, Intel and Mozilla Corporation. She was also a Senior Security Strategist at Microsoft. She is co-author of Threat Modeling, a standard manual on application security.
Inventor of the toggling whaling harpoon head
Blue baby syndrome treatment in the 1940s

First person to prove that insects can hear and can distinguish pitch, that cockroaches can learn by trial and error, and that honeybees can see color; first black person to receive a PhD from the University of Chicago
Program Director, Division of Musculoskeletal Diseases, at National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases, National Institutes of Health

Dorothy Johnson Vaughan (1910 – 2008) was an American mathematician and human computer who worked for the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA), and NASA, at Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia. In 1949, she became supervisor of the West Area Computers, the first African-American woman to supervise a group of staff at the center. During her 28-year career, Vaughan prepared for the introduction of machine computers in the early 1960s by teaching herself and her staff the programming language of Fortran. She later headed the programming section of the Analysis and Computation Division (ACD) at Langley.

Powtawche Valerino is an American mechanical engineer at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory. She worked as a navigation engineer for the Cassini mission. Her most recent project was the Parker Solar Probe spacecraft, which launched on August 12, 2018. It became the first satellite to fly as close to the sun as Helios 2 did in 1976.
Developed normal incidence multilayer XUV telescopes to photograph the solar corona

Created black cosmetic products - an African American entrepreneur, philanthropist, and political and social activist. She is recorded as the first black female self-made millionaire in America in the Guinness Book of World Records.
Washington is an internationally recognized expert in atmospheric sciences and climate research specializing in computer modeling of the Earth's climate.
Co-developed the foil electret microphone
Entered University of Chicago at age 13; PhD at 19; worked on the Manhattan Project; wrote over 100 scientific papers; helped recruit minorities into the sciences
The first black person on record to have successfully performed pericardium (the sac surrounding the heart) surgery to repair a wound.
Known for studies in topology and innovations in the field of mathematics

Williams was the John M. Olin Distinguished Professor of Economics at George Mason University, as well as a syndicated columnist and author. Known for his classical liberal and libertarian views, Williams's writings frequently appeared in Townhall, WND, and Jewish World Review.
Invented the synchronous multiplex railway telegraph
Noted for her contributions to chemotherapy and for pioneering the use of the drug methotrexate to treat breast cancer and skin cancer
Led team that first used Aureomycin as a treatment on humans
Roger Arliner Young (1899 – November 9, 1964) was an American scientist of zoology, biology, and marine biology. She was the first African American woman to receive a doctorate degree in zoology
Inventor of the Gong and Signal Chair and second black woman to receive a patent in the United States
